WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. Annie O'Connell
Address: Sagriff, Sask.
Birthplace: Bantock, Ont.

1. INTERESTING QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1910
Where did you set up housekeeping? Sagriff, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Plano, Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals? 5
How far was it to your nearest store? 7 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a month (about)
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Gold standard flour, corn meal, flour, breakfast cereal, cracked wheat, Ogilvie raisin in large wooden boxes.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Ogilvie
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 pounds
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.00
How much did you use graham flour? None
Whole wheat flour? Very little
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 7 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes
Whole wheat? Very little
Farine? None
Other? Rolled oats
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Some times
How did you grind it? Grain chopper at Mill, Balgonie, Sagriff

Corn meal, flour, apples, potatoes, and other vegetables

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We had our own cows first, then the following:

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? No.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? We bought at the butcher shop first, then raised our own.

How did you get fresh meat? Raised it on the farm.

How often did you get fresh meat? Bought it at the shop.

How did you preserve meat? By freezing water.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Sometimes. What kinds? Prarie chicken, ducks in season.

For how long? When ever available.

What part did fish play in the family diet? We bought it fresh in the winter.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds? White fish, Jack mostly.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Pail & barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We have bored well now and engine on pump. Cement cistern in basement with force pump attached bringing water to kitchen.

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood, W. Lawless, wood.

Where did you get your fuel? From the brick yard & bought 20 to 30 miles from 9/12. We started to burn coal.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We still use a coal range and a coal furnace. In 1914 built new house & had a furnace installed.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge, Bread or toast, Syrup or honey, jam, tea milk sugar, sometimes meat.

Dinner: Meat potatoes, Bread butter, one vegetable, pickles, rice pudding, milk, tea.

Supper: Hot potatoes, meat or eggs, sauce, Bread butter, usually cake or cookies, tea milk.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

It likely was Roast chicken, Steam pudding, potato puffs, pickles, Bread & Butter, tea & milk.

I can't remember who was there.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We have always had enough to eat. There is always plenty on the farm. If we look ahead and raise a few cattle, pigs, poultry etc. We have a grain farm, so never have gone in for live stock very extensively. A few cows to ship cream or make butter, some beef to sell, usually about four or five. Sometimes when the crops were bad in the thirties we had about 40 pigs to sell. When the crops were poor we tried to have more live stock. We never bought more than we could pay for anything. In the end it pays. We didn't have to worry about our debts.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for each year. Include the amount of food purchased and the total cost.

Breakfast: Porridge. Bread & toast. Syrup or honey. Jam.

Tea. Milk sugar. Sometimes meat.

Dinner: Meat potatoes. Bread & milk. One vegetable.

Pickles, sometimes pickling milk, tea. Bread.

Supper: Hot potatoes, meat & eggs. Dinner. Bread.

Droppe hot potatoes, usually cake or cornbread. Tea milk.

18. What did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Likely was:

Stuffed chicken. Steam pudding. Potato puffs.

Pickles. Bread & butter tea & milk.

I can't remember who was there.

19. How much money did you have to spend? Give details.

We always had enough to eat.

There is always plenty on the farm. We look ahead and raise after cattle, pigs, poultry etc. We have a grain farm. As much land as we can get. We have gone in for live stock only recently.

A few cows to ship cream or make butter. Some beef & milk, usually about $500 a year.

One time when the crops were bad in the thirties we had about $400 to sell, buying the crops were poor we tried to have more live stock.

We always bought more than we could pay for anything.

In the end it pays. We didn't have to worry about our debts.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In the early days a meal was mostly cooked the same day it was eaten. Now we can meat, vegetables, fruits, puddings so that we can get a meal on very short notice, so it is all prepared needing only to be heated up.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We buy most of our canned tomatoes, strawberries, raspberries, jam, as for other canned goods we have never bought very much of it. We have nearly always had as much of our own, we buy salmon, sardines, a can occasionally. They were all in the store in 1910.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

I think fruit to can has been our greatest problem. Sometimes there were plenty of raspberries. In 1912 we picked an abundance of wild strawberries on Mr John Douglas' farm at Asquith. Those are the only strawberries I ever remember picking. After that year the land was broken. The rest of the fruit we have always bought. The Asquith district has been a good place to live in. We have made many life long friends and we have the very finest neighbors. And we have prospered.
In the early days a meal was mostly cooked the same day it was eaten.

Now we can make vegetables, fruits, puddings so that we can put a meal on any shelf in notice, do it so all prepared needing only to be heated up.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods instead of home grown and home preserved foods? (Give as many details as possible).

We buy most of our canned tomatoes, strawberries, raspberries, etc., from other canned goods we have never bought very much of it. We have nearly always had so much of our own, we try to maintain a can reserve. They were all in the place in 1910.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and obtaining foods in other ways during pioneer days in the town.

Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

I think fruit is the best thing there was plenty of strawberries. In 1912 we picked an abundance of wild strawberries on Mr. John Simpson's farm at Agincourt. Those are the only strawberries I ever remember picking. After that year the land was broken. He went to the fruit district far from a good place to live in. We have made many life long friends. And we have the very finest neighbors. And we have prospered.
